info.text:
Questions about conflict negotiation based on Lewicki, Roy J., Bruce Barry, and David M. Saunders. 2016. Essentials of Negotiation. Sixth Edition.
Dubuque: McGraw-Hill Education.

questiontext.text: According to the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition by Lewicki, Roy J., Bruce Barry, and David M. Saunders some of the characteristics common to all negotiation situations are:

generalfeedback.text: Checkout Chapter 1 pages 6-9 in the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition

answer.text: There is a conflict between the parties involved, they prefer to search for an agreement rather than to fight openly and they think they can get a better deal by reaching an agreement
The parties involved have opposing interests, they do not contemplate scenarios where negotiating is not optimal or efficient and they need to manage the tangibles and intangibles items
The participants engage in a “give-and-take” process because of its conflicting interests, they avoid the influence of psychological motivations and they focused on the tangible aspects

questiontext.text: According to the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition by Lewicki, Roy J., Bruce Barry, and David M. Saunders if negotiating is conceived as a strategy to manage conflict we can conclude that:

generalfeedback.text: Checkout Chapter 1 pages 20-21 in the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition

answer.text: The objective of negotiators is not to eliminate conflict but to learn how to manage it to control its destructive elements in the negotiation process
The objective of negotiators is to eliminate conflict taking into account the dysfunctional aspects of it and the negative effects produced over the negotiation
The objective of negotiators is to avoid conflict taking into account that the costs related to the dysfunctions of conflict overcome the productive aspects of it

questiontext.text: According to the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition by Lewicki, Roy J., Bruce Barry, and David M. Saunders one of the dilemmas of mutual adjustment is:

generalfeedback.text: Checkout Chapter 1 pages 14-15 in the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition

answer.text: How much truth to tell the counterpart without giving them the opportunity to take advantage or destroying the process of creating trust
How much information given from the counterpart should negotiators use in formulating a negotiation strategy to take advantage of the situation
How much you should trust the counterpart in the process of planning a negotiation and finding an optimal solution to make concessions

questiontext.text: According to the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition by Lewicki, Roy J., Bruce Barry, and David M. Saunders the concept of interdependence in a negotiation context refers to:

generalfeedback.text: Checkout Chapter 1 page 10 in the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition

answer.text: The parties involved need to coordinate or choose to work together despite their opposing interests because the outcome is better in relation to a situation where they work by their own
The parties involved reason strategically taking into account the expectations and behavior of the counterpart to decide the course of action when adopting a joint decision in the negotiation
The parties in the negotiation take into consideration the possible decisions or strategies of the other parts involved and their similar, opposed or mixed interests when formulating a strategy

questiontext.text: According to the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition by Lewicki, Roy J., Bruce Barry, and David M. Saunders in a zero-sum negotiation situation:

generalfeedback.text: Checkout Chapter 1 pages 15-16 in the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition

answer.text: The typical approach is to use win–lose tactics and adopt a distributive bargaining style which implies claiming value
The usual approach is to use win–win strategies and adopt an integrative negotiation which implies creating value
The best option is to use a mix set of win–lose and win–win approaches which implies first claiming and then creating value

questiontext.text: According to the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition by Lewicki, Roy J., Bruce Barry, and David M. Saunders some of the tactics to close a deal are:

generalfeedback.text: Checkout Chapter 2 pages 49-50 in the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition

answer.text: Saving a special concession at the end of the negotiation and providing different available alternatives to the counterpart
Proposing an exaggerated opening offer and then splitting the difference, avoiding in that way the use of a hard ball tactical
Offering an appropriate deadline in order to pressure the counterpart through the use of selective presentation methods

questiontext.text: According to the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition by Lewicki, Roy J., Bruce Barry, and David M. Saunders the position of the authors in relation to the use of hardball tactics is the following:

generalfeedback.text: Checkout Chapter 2 pages 50-51 in the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition

answer.text: The authors don’t recommend the use of hardball tactics because they do more harm than good in a negotiation context
The authors recommend the use of hardball tactics because it is an appropriate and legitimate way to pressure the counterpart
The authors recommend not analyzing at all the hardball tactics in the context of negotiation because they are unethical tactics

name.text: Positions taken during distributive bargaining situations

questiontext.text: According to the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition by Lewicki, Roy J., Bruce Barry, and David M. Saunders in the context of a distributive bargaining situation taking positions covers some of the following elements:

generalfeedback.text: Checkout Chapter 2 pages 42-49 in the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition

answer.text: Defining the opening offer, the attitude to adopt during the negotiation, the possible concessions to be made and conveying the message to signal the final offer
Obtaining information about the BATNA, resistance point and costs of terminating the negotiations of the counterpart and planning the tactics to a close the deal
Assessing the potential settlement points that may occur in a negotiation to establish a strategy and identifying hardball tactics during negotiation to deal with them

questiontext.text: According to the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition by Lewicki, Roy J., Bruce Barry, and David M. Saunders some of the tactical tasks in a distributive bargaining situation are:

generalfeedback.text: Checkout Chapter 2 pages 36-42 in the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition

answer.text: Manipulating the costs of delay in a negotiation by for example increasing the cost of not reaching an agreement and modify the counterpart perceptions by for example making outcomes appear less attractive

Managing the counterpart impressions in a negotiation by for example omitting information relevant to the negotiation and assess the counterpart aspiration, resistance and initial points by for example a forward assessment

Controlling the information sent to the counterpart in relation to one’s BATNA by for example applying an indirect assessment and assessing the counterpart target and resistance points by for example using screening activities

questiontext.text: According to the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition by Lewicki, Roy J., Bruce Barry, and David M. Saunders the target point in a distributive bargaining situation refers to:

generalfeedback.text: Checkout Chapter 2 pages 29-30 in the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition

answer.text: The point where a negotiator would like to conclude negotiations
The point where a negotiator will not go in a negotiation situation
The first point a negotiator will quote to the counterpart when negotiating

questiontext.text: According to the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition by Lewicki, Roy J., Bruce Barry, and David M. Saunders an accommodative strategy is used to:

generalfeedback.text: Checkout Chapter 4 pages 92-94 in the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition

answer.text: Build a trust relationship with the counterpart by accepting a suboptimal outcome to ask for reciprocity in the future
Establish a long term relation with the counterpart to work together in the future and to find mutually satisfying solutions
Adopt a win-lose strategy relationship to subordinate the counterpart and mitigate the conflict by maintaining at all cost the harmony

name.text: Assessing the Social Context of Negotiation

questiontext.text: According to the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition by Lewicki, Roy J., Bruce Barry, and David M. Saunders assessing the social context of the negotiation, refers to:

generalfeedback.text: Checkout Chapter 4 pages 104-112 in the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition

answer.text: Analyzing the coalitions, constituents, observers and rules that may affect in a direct or indirect way the negotiation dynamics
Assessing your own targets and initial offer where it may affect the context in which a settlement can be achieved with the counterpart
Planning the process and structuring the context by which information is presented that may affect the negotiation agenda

name.text: Defining the Major Issue Related to Achieving the Goal

questiontext.text: According to the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition by Lewicki, Roy J., Bruce Barry, and David M. Saunders defining the major issue to achieve the goal, refers to:

generalfeedback.text: Checkout Chapter 4 pages 97-100 in the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition

answer.text: Analyzing what are the key issues to be discussed in the negotiation which will determine if it would be a single-issue or multiple-issue negotiation
Identifying the tangible, intangible and procedural elements of the negotiation which will impact on the choice of strategy adopted by the negotiator
Assembling the different issues, ranking their importance and defining the bargaining mix to establish what are the items to be discussed in the negotiation

name.text: Goals: The Focus That Drives a Negotiation Strategy

questiontext.text: According to the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition by Lewicki, Roy J., Bruce Barry, and David M. Saunders the determination of goals in a negotiation implies:

generalfeedback.text: Checkout Chapter 4 pages 89-92 in the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition

answer.text: Identifying a measurable, specific and concrete target point to determine what as a negotiator I want to achieve in a negotiation
Specifying the possible concrete wishes that I want to attain as a negotiator before establishing a negotiation strategic plan
Examining the realistic boundaries or limits that I may offer to the counterpart taking into account the procedural aspects

questiontext.text: According to the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition by Lewicki, Roy J., Bruce Barry, and David M. Saunders knowing your limits, refers to:

generalfeedback.text: Checkout Chapter 4 pages 100-104 in the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition

answer.text: Identifying your own resistance point to avoid agreeing to non beneficial proposals during the negotiation
Identifying your own best alternative to a negotiation agreement to avoid accepting non beneficial offers
Identifying your own capacity to analyze and understand the counterpart goals, issues and resistance points

questiontext.text: According to the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition by Lewicki, Roy J., Bruce Barry, and David M. Saunders the cognitive bias known as availability of information refers to:

generalfeedback.text: Checkout Chapter 6 pages 153-154 in the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition

answer.text: A situation where negotiators give more prominence to information that is more readily available in contrast to information that is more critical
A situation where negotiators, based on a restricted information set, tend to quickly settle on an outcome and then feel discomfort about this result
A situation where there is a tendency of negotiators to assume that their ability to be correct or accurate is greater than is actually true based on biased information

questiontext.text: According to the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition by Lewicki, Roy J., Bruce Barry, and David M. Saunders the cognitive bias known as endowment effect refers to:

generalfeedback.text: Checkout Chapter 6 pages 154-156 in the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition

answer.text: A situation where individuals have a tendency to inflate the value of something they own or have in their possession
A situation where individuals usually draw inappropriately conclusions based on tiny or small data samples
A situation where individuals discard the counterpart concessions simply because the other party made them

questiontext.text: According to the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition by Lewicki, Roy J., Bruce Barry, and David M. Saunders the cognitive bias known as fixed-pie beliefs refers to:

generalfeedback.text: Checkout Chapter 6 pages 151-152 in the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition

answer.text: A situation where negotiators assume that all negotiations are zero-sum situations
A situation where negotiators tend to persist in pursuing a failing course of action
A situation where negotiators are overly influenced by an anchor or reference point

questiontext.text: According to the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition by Lewicki, Roy J., Bruce Barry, and David M. Saunders a frame refers to:

generalfeedback.text: Checkout Chapter 6 pages 142-149 in the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition

answer.text: A subjective mechanism of interpretation by which individuals evaluate, understand and make sense of the situations they face
The process by which a situation can be shaped as a function of information and communication during a negotiation
A perceptual distortion where negotiators assign to others the characteristics or feelings that they possess themselves

questiontext.text: According to the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition by Lewicki, Roy J., Bruce Barry, and David M. Saunders the perceptual distortion, refers to:

generalfeedback.text: Checkout Chapter 6 pages 140-142 in the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition

answer.text: The predisposition that a negotiator has in relation to the counterpart which may generate biases and usually errors in the negotiation process
The process by which individuals connect to their environment and that may affect negatively the context in which a negotiation take place
The stereotypes and selective perceptions that surge in a negotiation as a result of distortions that arise on the part of the participants in a negotiation

questiontext.text: According to the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition by Lewicki, Roy J., Bruce Barry, and David M. Saunders in the context of a negotiation the contextual source of power refers to:

generalfeedback.text: Checkout Chapter 8 pages 197-199 in the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition

answer.text: The power derived from the environment aspects in which the social context of the negotiation develops
The power that surge from the context in which the parties share their goals and the respect the negotiator reflects
The setting in which the legitimate power is build and the context in which the tangible rewards are given in a negotiation

name.text: Dealing with Others Who Have More Power

questiontext.text: According to the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition by Lewicki, Roy J., Bruce Barry, and David M. Saunders some ways to deal with other parties who have more power are:

generalfeedback.text: Checkout Chapter 8 pages 199-201 in the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition

answer.text: Attempt to engage in multiple negotiations by establishing multiple relationships to diversify risk and make coalitions with low-power players to increase the collective bargaining power
Don’t establish preliminary relationships with the counterpart so you don’t share vital information and use an “all-or-nothing deal” strategy to generate momentum using a credible threat
Make multiple offers to more than one high-power party so they will compete between each other and as a low-power party take higher risks because you can adapt faster in a negotiation

questiontext.text: According to the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition by Lewicki, Roy J., Bruce Barry, and David M. Saunders power is understood as:

generalfeedback.text: Checkout Chapter 8 pages 183-185 in the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition

answer.text: A tool to dominate and control the counterpart or a relationship were the power holder act together with the counterpart by sharing its capacity to dominate
The capacity of a negotiator to influence in his overall environment by modifying the resistance and target points of the counterpart in a negotiation
An ability where a negotiator can influence the settlement point in a negotiation by understanding the interests of the counterpart and creating value

questiontext.text: According to the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition by Lewicki, Roy J., Bruce Barry, and David M. Saunders in the context of a negotiation the informational source of power refers to:

generalfeedback.text: Checkout Chapter 8 pages 186-188 in the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition

answer.text: The ability of a negotiator to collect and organize information that supports his position, arguments and target point with the objective to change the counterpart point of view
The advantage of being in a particular location of an informational or communication structure by controlling the flow of information and altering the bargaining process
The capacity of a negotiator to understand the behavioral information of the counterpart in relation to its motivational, disposition, moral motivation and personality qualities

name.text: Why Is Power Important to Negotiators?

questiontext.text: According to the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition by Lewicki, Roy J., Bruce Barry, and David M. Saunders power is important to negotiators because:

generalfeedback.text: Checkout Chapter 8 pages 182-183 in the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition

answer.text: It is a way to minimize the probability of a dominant relation or to gain an advantage by blocking the counterpart actions in a negotiation
It is a method to pressure the other party by adopting an offensive posture so the counterpart will adopt a collaborative or compromising stance
It is a strategy to gain or sustain one’s own advantage in future negotiations with the mainly objective of leveling the playing field efficiently

questiontext.text: According to the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition by Lewicki, Roy J., Bruce Barry, and David M. Saunders the approach to end-result ethics refers to:

generalfeedback.text: Checkout Chapter 5 pages 116-119 in the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition

answer.text: An ethical reasoning where the rightness of a decision depends only on the consequences generated by this particular decision excluding other possible aspects
An ethical reasoning where the determination of the rightness related to a particular decision depends only on the norms and customs of a specific community
An ethical reasoning where the level of rightness of a particular action is determined by applying universal standards, general principles or rules of conduct

name.text: Dealing with deception by the counterpart

questiontext.text: According to the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition by Lewicki, Roy J., Bruce Barry, and David M. Saunders a way to deal with deceptive tactics applied by the counterpart is to:

generalfeedback.text: Checkout Chapter 5 page 133-137 in the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition

answer.text: Asking specific an concrete questions to the counterpart to collect information and detect with higher probability misinterpretations by commission or omission
Make a credible threat to the counterpart and assume a dominating and coercive stance so the counterpart will back off from using this type of tactics
Apply a distributive style of negotiation by being aggressive and mimicking the behavior of the counterpart to level the field in the bargaining process

questiontext.text: According to the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition by Lewicki, Roy J., Bruce Barry, and David M. Saunders a misrepresentation by omission refers to:

generalfeedback.text: Checkout Chapter 5 page 125-126 in the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition

answer.text: A situation in which the negotiator fails to disclose relevant information that will benefit the counterpart in a negotiation context
A strategy where an unethical action is committed in a negotiation by lying directly and omitting information about owns resistance point
A deceptive tactic where its use, in a negotiation context, depends on whether it produces the desire result and how the negotiator is judge by the counterpart

questiontext.text: According to the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition by Lewicki, Roy J., Bruce Barry, and David M. Saunders a motive and a consequence of using deceptive tactics are:

generalfeedback.text: Checkout Chapter 5 page 126-131 in the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition

answer.text: Using deceptive tactics is a way to increase the power of a negotiator in a bargaining process but the problem is that if the counterpart is aware of the use of this type of tactics will not trust the negotiator in future encounters

Applying these tactics occurs because the negotiator is in a situation where doesn’t find another plausible alternative but the problem is that in future negotiations these tactics will not be effective because they become predictable

A possible explanation is that negotiators assume that they are always negotiating in a pure distributive or zero sum context but later in the negotiation they will feel guilty and will tend to make higher concessions to the counterpart

questiontext.text: According to the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition by Lewicki, Roy J., Bruce Barry, and David M. Saunders in the context of ethically ambiguous tactics, ethics in negotiation focus on:

generalfeedback.text: Checkout Chapter 5 pages 116-119 in the book Essentials of Negotiation (2016) Sixth Edition

answer.text:
Establishing the standards of truth telling in relation to what negotiators say or what they say they will

do in a negotiation context
Specifying the appropriate rules of conduct in relation to what negotiators actually do in relation to inappropriate behavior
Pointing out the rightness of a negotiation strategy by examining its consequences or applying universal standards and principles
